Name: None
Description: No leader

Name: William of Normandy
Description: William the Bastard, William the Duke of Normandy, William the Conqueror, was the first Norman to rule over England after wrestling the control from the Anglo-Saxon king, Harold Godwinson, in the invasion of England in 1066. From the still young House of Normandy, which ruled over the Normandy region since 911, William was one of the prime contenders whom King Edward the Confessor appoint as his heir. The throne of England is always in his destiny and nothing will stop his rightful conquest.
para1: William of house Normandy, an illegitimate son of Robert I the Magnificent (hence the nickname “the Bastard”), was born around 1027 AD. He became the Duke of Normandy at the age of 8 but his rise was nothing short of challenging due to his birth status. Many nobles attempted to gain custody of the young duke or organise rebellions to seize the dukedom. With the support of King Henry I of France and many prominent nobles, William managed to consolidate the region of Normandy under his rule in the end.
para2: William first experience in warfare began in the Battle of Varaville, 1047 AD, against a rebellion led by Guy of Burgundy and the fellow conspirators. With the support of King Henry I who personally raised an army of 10,000 strongs to support William's much smaller army, they managed to win against the less organised rebel army, while being outnumbered by at least 2 to 1. The battle ended prematurely after the rebel army became disheartened after losing multiple cavalry skirmishes and broken apart.
para3: After crushing the rebels in the Battle of Varaville, William continuously removed those who threaten his rule in a series of battles and sieges. After his rule of Normandy was firmly in place, William never stop expanding his influence, which ultimately caused great concern to both the French King, Henry I, and his court. Thus, Henry I and multiple French and Norman nobles marched to seize control of Normandy. Two invasions were attempted which result in the Battle of Mortemer in 1054 AD and Battle of Varaville in 1057 AD.
para4: With Normandy now under his control, William expanded his control even further with the Invasion of Brittany in 1064 AD, only two years before the England invasion. Although the exact purpose of this invasion is not recorded, William managed to secure the border and also gained many Breton allies who will assist in the upcoming invasion. Additionally, it is with this invasion that multiple Norman sided sources claim Harold Godwinson assisted William in the invasion and promised to help him secure the throne of England.
para5: Edward the Confessor recently passed away in 1066 AD and Harold proclaimed himself as King of England. William, who also claim to receive such blessing from King Edward, prepared an invasion to claim his rightful throne. Two war councils were called to plan the invasion and multiple prominent rulers at the time seem to support the invasion including the pope himself. William's army was assembled and the fleet was constructed in Normandy.
para6: Interestingly, the initial beginning of the invasion did not go well, the strong wind caused a major delay to the invasion, loss of fleet portion and decrease in the morale. This misfortune, however, creates a significant adventurous turn of event for William as King Harald of Norway arrived a few days earlier at Northumbrian coast. This cause Harold to march his army up north to deal with the Norwegian invasion and allows William's force to land safely at Pevensey Bay with plenty of time to recuperate.
para8: Picture: William holding a feast after fleet landing.
para9: In the Battle of Hastings, William positioned his Conroi knights contingent behind the frontline during the initial phase of the battle. It is very likely that in the melee phase in mid-day that he personally led the charge into the enemy infantry line. If the chronicle to be believed, William was unhorsed and almost got killed multiple times in battle, which can be the cause of rumour of his death among the troop. At the end of the day, William managed to win against all odds and came out victorious.
para11: Picture: William in battle openning his                                        helmet to prove that he was still alive                                       and rally his men.
para12: After the battle, William marched his army to London while also spreading his force to crush the remaining Saxon resistance around the country. Upon reaching London, William ordered the construction of the Tower of London to fortified the capital. He was coronated as the king of England at Westminster Abbey on Christmas day, 1066 AD.  The English throne would then no longer be a dream but a reality. Thus marked the end of Saxon influence in England and the Norman conquest.
para13: With William as now king, he replaced the old Saxon law and culture with the Norman one. Many former Saxon nobles were replaced with those who accompanied William in the invasion. Unsurprisingly, many remaining Saxon nobles would continue the resistance for the years to come. Even worse, King Sweyn II of Denmark supported the rebellion and mobilised his army for invasion. The resistance would continue for no less than two more decades after the end of conquest.
para14: William's ruling over England is not much different from his prior approach in Normandy. The constant internal conflicts, rebellion and left the country in a constant state of warfare. Not only that, many of his campaigns were considered to be genocidal in nature by many scholars today, though not really uncommon in the Medieval era. Nevertheless, his military achievement is no doubt one of the deservingly critical acclaimed by historians today.
para15: His story did not conclude elegantly even in his death. His lifeless body went rotten before the burial ceremony, and it swelled up to the point that it exploded when stuffed inside the coffin. His throne also did not pass on peacefully for succession rebellion between his two sons occurred only one year after, and the rule of his son (Rufus, the one who won) too ended tragically with an arrow to the chest.

Name: Alan the Red
Description: Alan Rufus or "the Red (beard)" was a Breton nobleman and close companion of William the Conqueror. As part of the Invasion of England, he is the commander of the Breton force in William's army. After the successful invasion, Alan was granted amass fortune and the title Earl of Richemont and remain an important figure in William's court and ruling achievement, which later on allows him to become one of the wealthiest individuals in Europe.
para1: Alan Rufus (the Red), son of Eudon (Odo) of Brittany and Orguen, was born around 1040 AD in Brittany. He was from House of Rennes and a relative of William the Bastard. Evident records seem to suggest that Alan was William's companion and held a sizable amount of lands and estates long before the Invasion of England. However not much else is known about Rufus in his early life before the Battle of Hastings but much of his legacies still live on to this day.
para2: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\alan_1.png
para3: Picture: William the Conqueror granting the charter with a green pendant seal representing lordship of Richmondshire to Alan Rufus.
para4: Alan's accomplishment in the Battle of Hastings was noteworthy indeed. He was a commander for one of the Breton contingents, probably the infantry lines, and he was commended for merit in battle by various chronicles. For his contribution to the battle, Alan was greatly rewarded with a vast amount of wealth and lands in central England similar to other William's prominent companions. Alan remained a loyal subject of the Norman English throne until the end.
para5: After the invasion, Alan participated in the quelling of the Saxon rebellion in 1069 AD. Although unclear what kind of role he had in the conflict, Alan was rewarded Honour of Richmond, the region of Yorkshire. There Alan built Richmond Castle in 1071 AD that still stands to this day, albeit as a ruin that reflects only the glory of its former self. As time went by, Alan's wealth and power grew larger. By 1086 AD, Alan Rufus was one of the wealthiest and powerful individuals in England.
para8: Picture: Watercolour of Richmond Castle in the late 18th century, by Paul Sandby and William Taverner.
para9: In the later part of his life, Alan participated in various internal conflict and rebellion on the side of the royal throne. Even in the rebellion in 1088 AD, Alan supported William II to protect the throne against Robert Curthose, William's eldest son. Victorious in various battles and contributed greatly to the war effort, Alan remained powerful in the English court, possibly only second to the king himself, unlike many other former companions of William.
para10: Alan Rufus died suddenly and somewhat mysteriously either in 1090 or 1093 AD of unknown cause. His body was buried in an abbey at Bury St Edmunds, an eventful region on its own. Without children, Alan's brother, Alan Niger (the Black), inherited the title and treasure of the wealthiest individual in English history and remained as the second lord until his too inevitable death.

Name: William FitzOsbern
Description: William fitzOsbern was a cousin and close companion of William the Conqueror. He was a nobleman who rules over Breteuil, Normandy before becoming Earl of Hereford and Essex after Norman conquest. After the invasion, he remained one of the most important political figures in Norman England, while his name became and is still renown for many castles that he commissioned. He met his end in the Battle of Cassel while persuing the wealth of Flanders principality.
para1: William FitzOsbern was born in 1020 AD, son of Osbern the seneschal of Normandy and Emma of Ivry. His family served the Duke of Normandy for generations and was a closed relative to the House of Normandy. With his father murdered in 1040, William FitzOsbern became the next seneschal for William the Bastard and one of the closest advisors to the duke. It is believed that being the most zealous supporter for the Invasion of England, he was the one that persuaded the opposition nobles to join the invasion.
para2: With the successful conquest and as one of the leading figures in the invasion, William FitzOsbern was generously rewarded and granted the lordship over Isle of Wight and Hereford to already many of land-ownership under his rule. The promise of peace is still not in sight for England as the region near Wales (commonly called The Welsh Marches) was still under threat from the hostile Welsh Kingdom, William FitzOsbern was assigned as the chief strategist to create a new type of stone castle to defend the border.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\ozborn_1.png
para4: Many stone castles did he build and still standing until this day, William became one of the major Norman castle builders. One of them being Chepstow Castle in the southeast of Wales, which is now the oldest stone castle that is still standing today in Britain as seen in the picture above.
para5: William became one of the most prominent political figures in the Norman court. He was assigned the commander of the royal army and in charge of many regions, both as the regents and governor. The tales of this famed castle builder does not have a pleasant ending however as William saw an opportunity over the now contesting Flenders region. He decided to marry the widowed countess Richilde and rushed to her aid in the succession dispute conflict.
para6: William joined the Battle of Cassel with a group of Norman Conrois against Robert I of Flenders in February 1071 AD. Both Arnulf III, the leader of the army, and William were killed in the surprise attack organised by Robert. His estates and wealth were then divided among his two sons, William and Roger FitzOsbern.

Name: Eustace II
Description: Eustace II was a Count of Boulogne who fought in the Battle of Hastings. He was one of the commanders that lead the charge of Norman Knights and was struck by a battle-axe from Saxon Huscarl in the battle. After the invasion, Eustace rebelled against William the Conqueror due to the dissatisfaction of war spoil and possibly for a claim on the English throne. The rebellion ultimately failed but William and Eustace reconciled with Eustace retained some of his holdings and remained in William's court.
para1: Eustace II (Nickname Eustace with moustaches) was born between the year 1015 and 1018 AD, son of Eustace I of Boulogne and Matilda of Louvaine. He participated in the failed rebellion in 1033 AD against Henry III, emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, and was excommunicated by Pope Leo IX in 1049 AD for marrying his second wife, Ida of Lorraine, a close relative to Eustace after his first wife died a decade ago. Eustace also became the Count of Boulogne as his father died in the same year.
para2: In 1051 AD, Eustace visited Edward the confessor who was his relative and ally. A simple visit created a turn of event when Eustace and his retinue somehow got into a brawl with the people of Dovers. A minor event that led to the rebellion and exile of House Godwinson later on. Eustace joined Duke William of Normandy in the Invasion of England and seem to be one of the important commanders in the army. His role in the battle was noteworthy in many chronicles.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\eustace_1.png
para4: Picture: Eustace in the battle pointing at Duke William and yelling to the troop that William is still here and alive.
para5: As the battle turning worse for Norman side, the Norman record writes that as Eustace was about to retreat with his knights, Duke William's reinforcement arrived at the central engagement. Eustace advised the Duke that the army should withdraw but was ignored. As the fight continued, Eustace was struck in the face by a Saxon soldier that caused blood to gushed from his mouth and nose. Nevertheless, Eustace survived the battle.
para6: Although Eustace joined William in the invasion, many pieces of evidence seem to suggest that this is not out of loyalty and friendship. It is also possible that Eustace looked down on William for being a bastard with commoner blood, while he was part of the illustrated House of Flenders. This matter reinforces the fact that Eustace's role in battle varied widely in different chronicles, some depict him as a coward while some others depict him as a competent warrior and commander.
para7: After the invasion, Eustace was granted reward and land for his contribution to the invasion and returned to his holding in Boulogne. In 1067 AD, Eustace launched an attack on Odo of Bayeux's castle in Dover, which ultimately failed. The reason for the attack is not clear, some suggested that it is rebellion for him being unsatisfied with the amount of reward from the invasion, while others suggest he was "requested" by his Englishmen allies who also joined the siege.
para8: Eustace managed to flee from the failed rebellion back to Boulogne. He was stripped of his title and lordship in England when William heard of the rebellion. William later forgave Eustace and returned some of the confiscated lands soon later. Many scholars also suggest that it was Eustace who commisioned the Bayeux Tepastry and presented it to Odo of Bayeux to make amend for trying to attack Dover castle. This would explained why Eustace was depicted positively in the Tepastry.
para9: Eustace remained a powerful figure in Flenders region as the Count of Boulogne until he died in 1087 AD possibly of old age at around 70 years old.

Name: William d'Evreux
Description: William d'Evreux was a Norman nobleman who fought alongside William the Conqueror in the Battle of Hastings and contributed to the construction of Norman fleet. Not much is known of his personal role in the battle, but after the invasion, William was granted multiple landholdings but no noteworthy nobility title from the war contribution. Later on in his life, William inherited Count of Evreux from his father and participate in many battles likes Battle of Tinchebray under King Henry I.
para1: William of Evreux was born around 1046 AD in Evreux, son of Archbishop Richard of Evreux and Godchildis. Not much is known about his early life except that he was a prominent Norman noble who participated in the Invasion of England. William and along with his father participated in the Council at Lillebonne and contributed around 80 transport ships to the invasion fleet. Although not explicitly mentioned, it was very likely that William also fought in the Battle of Hastings.
para2: With the retirement of his father in 1066 AD, William succeeded as the Count of Evreux the next year after the invasion. He was modestly rewarded with chiefdoms in England for his contribution probably due to his young age compared to the other companions. After the invasion, William also participated in many other battles and conflicts including the 1088 rebellion on the side of William II of England. His name was also recorded in the Battle of Tinchebray in 1106 AD fighting for King Henry I as well.
para3: In the later part of his life, his wife, Hervise of Nevers who is the daughter of William the Conqueror, became the regent and ruled in his place. Her rule was reportedly efficient yet too audacious that William II exiled both William and his wife twice, both times due to the complaints by his own noble council. William died in 1118 AD at the age of around 70 years old and was buried in Fontenelle Abbey, Normandy, next to his father's grave. As he died childlessly, all of his possessions were seized by Henry I to prevent foreign inheritance by his French relative.

Name: Robert de Beaumont
Description: Robert de Beaumont was a Norman nobleman who fought in the Battle of Hastings on the side of William the Conqueror. It is believed that Robert fought with the French (Frank) troops on the right wing of the Norman army. He later became the County of Meulan after Count Hugh I, his uncle, died and Earl of Leicester during the reign of Henry I.
para1: Robert de Beaumont, born between 1040 and 1050 AD, was the son of Roger de Beaumont and Adeline de Meulan. No record of his achievement and early part of his life is known until his contribution in the Battle of Hastings where he personally fought under William of Normandy. He was the commander of the French infantry regiment on the right side of the army during the battle. He was rewarded for his accomplishment in battle with many English Manors in Warwickshire and Leicestershire.
para2: He inherited Count of Meulan from his mother in 1081 AD, he also inherited many titles and properties in the Frech region in the same year. In 1107 AD, Henry I of England created the title of Earl of Leicester and granted the title to Robert, making him the first Earl of Leicester in history, which would be inherited by his family for generations to come. Later on, Robert was excommunicated by Pope Paschal II in 1105 AD for his role in investiture (instalment freedom of bishop by the state/king instead of the Pope) in England.
para3: Robert was the last living Norman noble that fought in the Battle of Hastings to die in 1118 AD at the age of around 70 years old. The cause of death is not known but the story is that he died of shame for having the woman he fancied stolen by another nobleman. He was buried at Preaux Abbey and his son, Robert II inherited the title of Earl of Leicester and his other titles.

Name: Geoffrey II
Description: Geoffrey II was the Count of Mortagne and later Count of Perche who participated in Norman invasion and Battle of Hastings on William's side. After the invasion, he fought against Robert of Belleme, a prominent noble, in a land dispute but ultimately failed. Later on, he became renown for his spiritual pursuit and charitable acts such as establishing leper colonies, the place to keep leper isolated from society, in his region.
para1: Geoffrey II, son of Rotrou I and possibly Adeliza, was likely born between 1030 to 1040 AD by the estimation of his death in 1100 AD. He was one of the few named companions of William of Normandy in the Invasion of England. He inherited the title of Count of Mortagne when his father died in 1088 AD. Not much else is known about his early life and his contribution to the invasion but he was rewarded with a great amount of landholding in England.
para2: After becoming the Count, Geoffrey began the act to reform Saint-Denis of Nogent-le-Rotrou abbey's monastery to improve its monastic standard. Geoffrey also reputedly began a conflict with Robert of Belleme, his relative and a powerful Norman noble, over a failed land dispute. A historical account of Geoffrey's character seems to be that he is a handsome and brave leader with a strong religious belief. Geoffrey later focused his life in religious pursuit and built a leper colony in his domain.
para3: Geoffrey died in 1100 AD while his son, Rotrou II, was on the journey for the First Crusade. During Rotrou absence, Geoffrey's wife, Beatrix, became the regent for an unknown period of time.

Name: Aimery IV of Thouars
Description: Aimery (or Aimeri) IV of Thouars was a Viscount who fought against William the Conqueror in the Siege of Ambrieres. During the Norman invasion, he joined the Norman force and commanded the Breton wing of the army during the Battle of Hastings. After the invasion, he returned to his holding in France and ruled there for another three decades until he was assassinated.
para1: Aimery IV of Thouars, son of Geoffrey II of Thouars and Agnes de Blois, was born in 1024 AD. He was initially fought against William of Normandy when the French alliance invaded Normandy to halt William's expansion in 1055. He participated in the Siege of Ambrieres alongside Geoffrey II the Hammer (Martel). Aimery also participated in the Reconquista against the Moors and participate in the Crusade of Barbastro, sanctioned by Pope Alexander.
para2: Aimery joined William of Normandy in the Invasion of England in 1066 AD and commanded the Breton contingent on the left wing during the Battle of Hastings. After the successful invasion, he received great wealth as a reward and returned to France. Later in his life, Aimery focused on the development of his domain and fought against many other nobles in personal conflicts. He was assassinated by two of his own knights in 1093 AD and was buried in the Church of Saint Nicolas.

Name: Walter Giffard
Description: Walter Giffard was one of the closest companions of William the Conqueror who fought with him long before the Norman invasion. A veteran knight, landowner and later Baron of Long Crendon, Walter Giffard fought in the Reconquista against the Moors and contributed to the Norman invasion significantly and personally fought in the Battle of Hastings.
para1: Walter Giffard or Giffard of Barbastre, son of Osbern de Bolbec and Aveline de Crepon, was born around 1010 AD. He was a long time supporter and companion of William of Normandy. Walter participated in the defence against the invasion of Normandy against Henry I and also fought alongside with William in the Battle of Mortemer in 1054 AD. Walter also presented in the Siege of Arques castle during the Norman rebellion by William of Talou in the same year.
para2: Walter also joined in the Spanish Reconquista and took part in the Siege of Barbastro in 1064 AD. At the end of the crusade in 1065 AD, Walter returned to Normandy with great rewards from the Spanish king including a warhorse, which he presented to William of Normandy as a gift. This warhorse was the first horse that William rode in the Battle of Hastings. In 1066 AD, Walter accompanied William in the Invasion of England as a veteran knight who fought beside William during the Battle of Hastings.
para3: After the invasion, Walter was greatly rewarded with huge amount of estates and wealth. He was also granted the Barony of Long Crendon. Walter died sometimes around 1085 AD of unknown cause at the age of 74 - 75 years old. His body was buried alongside his family at Brewood, Staffordshire.

Name: Hugh de Montfort
Description: Hugh II de Montfort was a Norman nobleman from Montfort-sur-Risle who participated in the Battle of Hastings on the side of William the Conqueror. Hugh II was one of the major companions who fought alongside William long before the invasion and also participated Council of Lillebonne. Although his role in the Battle of Hastings is not evidently recorded, the numerous reward of holding from Domesday book evidence suggests that his contribution to the war and battle are likely to be significant.
para1: Hugh II de Montfort was born about 1020 AD in Montfort, Normandy. Son of Hugues I de Montfort and an unnamed mother. Hugh was one of the companions of William of Normandy since at least the Invasion of Normandy by King Henry I. He was one of the commanders in the Battle of Mortemer. Hugh also participated in the Invasion of England, he personally contributed both warships and knights to the army. It was very likely that he fought in the Battle of Hastings as well.
para2: After the invasion, Hugh was rewarded with manors and lands in Essex, Suffolk,  Norfolk,  Kent, and Romney Marsh. He was also appointed as the justice administrator for the Kingdom under Odo of Bayeux and William FitzOsbern. He was made the governor of Castle of Dover, Odo's main fortress. The castle which was attacked by Eustace II during his absence in 1067 AD. Hugh was killed in a duel With Wacheline de Ferrers at Abbey Of Bec in 1088 AD.

Name: Raoul II of Tosny
Description: A Norman nobleman of House Tosny, Raoul II of Tosny who fought on the side of William the Conqueror in the Battle of Mortimer. Later he also participated in the Battle of Hastings possibly fighting nearby the Duke himself. After the invasion, he was rewarded greatly by the now King William with lands and war spoils. However, his life was in no shortage of conflicts. He fought against William d'Evreux and later on against Robert de Beaumont.
para1: Raoul II of Tosny, son of Roger I of Tosny and Gotelina, was born around 1027 AD. Raoul was from the infamous House of Tosny created by his grandfather, Raoul I of Tosny "The Moor Eater" who literally ate the boiled Moorish prisoners of war. Not much story is known for Raoul II except that he was part of the invasion force who fought in the Battle of Hastings. It is said that he declined the role of standard-bearer so that he can fight nearby William of Normandy during the battle.
para2: Raoul remained as a noble in William's court after the invasion. He was rewarded handsomely with wealth and lands. Raoul II's life was never without conflict even after settling in England, he and William of Evreux started a short-lived personal war over the disagreement between their wife in 1091 AD. The two later reconciled and joined forces against Robert de Beaumont in the later conflict. Raoul had many estates and castle all over England, one of which still standing today at Conches-en-Ouche, Normandy.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\raoul_1.png
para4: Picture: The remnant of Conches-en-Ouche castle built by Raoul II.

Name: Hugh de Grandmesnil
Description: Hugh de Grandmesnil was one of the noble companions of William the Conqueror that originally got banished by William from Normandy but managed to regain the Duke's Favour again years later. He joined the Duke in Norman conquest and personally fought in multiple battles. He was rewarded handsomely with multiple landholdings and was appointed the Sheriff of Leicestershire. He remained an important political figure during William's reign and joined in a conflict against Robert de Beaumont.
para1: Hugh de Grandmesnil was born in 1032 AD, son of Robert of Grandmesnil and Hawise d'Echaffour. House of Grandmesnil was a Norman noble house that specialised in warhorse training, it was also an ally of House of Tosny against House of Beaumont. When his father died in a surprise attack conducted by the Beaumonts, Hugh and his brother, Robert, divided the inheritance. While his brother chose the life of a religious cleric, Hugh inherited his father's estate and focus his life in politic.
para2: Hugh was one of the key noblemen in William of Normandy's court. However, due to unfound paranoia of Hugh's increasing political influence, William banished Hugh in 1058 AD but the two reconciled in 1063 AD. Hugh joined William in the Invasion of England and served as a cavalry commander during the Battle of Hastings where he almost died in combat. Hugh was rewarded greatly with many manors and titles in England.
para3: After the invasion, Hugh remained a prominent political figure in William's court and was part of the council that administrated the kingdom during the king's absence. During this time, Hugh gained more favour from William and was rewarded greatly with even more titles and lands, although he never rose above his rank as a baron, a powerful one nonetheless. Even at old age, Hugh's rule was still rived with conflicts against other Norman nobles. He died of old age on his bed at Leicester in 1094 AD at the age of 66 years old.

Name: William de Warenne
Description: William de Warenne was among Norman nobles that participate in Council of Lillebonne and Norman invasion. After the successful invasion, he received numerous landholdings as a reward but remained somewhat minor noble in Norman court. Only later, He became Earl of Surrey during the reign of William the Conqueror's third son, William II Rufus (The Red) for his loyalty to the king during the rebellion. He fought against the rebels and met his end during the Siege of Pevensey Castle.
para1: William de Warenne was born possibly around 1040 AD in Flender, although no exact year is truly known. He is the son of Rodulf II de Warenne and Emma Torta de Pont-Audemer. His family was a small noble house under William of Normandy's rule before the invasion. William de Warenne participated in the Battle of Mortemer and became lord of Bellencombre and Mortimer in 1054. He also participated in the Council of Lillebonne and accompanied the Duke in the Invasion of England in 1066 AD.
para2: A capable commander and warrior since a young age, William undoubtedly accomplished significantly in the Battle of Hastings for he was generously rewarded with great amount of lands and holding despite being a minor noble. William later moved his main estate to Castle Acre in Norfolk. His political and monetary power became one of the highest among now King William the Conqueror's court. With lands stretching across England in at least 13 regions.
para4: His rule after the invasion was ruthless and expansionist. William was also part of the council noble under Odo of Bayeux and William Fitz 0sbern who administer the country during the King's absence. He participated in the noble rebellion suppression in 1071 and 1074 AD. William and his wife Gundred began a pilgrimage to Rome around 1080 AD. Their travel was cut short at Burgundy due to the war between Emperor Henry IV and Pope Gregory VII.
para6: Picture: Lewes Castle built by Wiiliam de Warenne that is still standing today.
para7: Impressed by the Italian monasteries they visited during the pilgrimage, William found a Cluniac priory in his domain at Lowes making it the first-ever Cluniac priory in England. He also strengthened his domain by starting to rebuild the Lowes Castle. He became Earl of Surrey during William II's reign and participated in the Siege of Saint-Suzanne on William II's side. He was wounded in the Siege of Pevensey Castle and died when he returned to Lewes.
para9: Picture: The arts of stolen leaden cists containing the remains of William and his wife, by Richard Henry Nibbs.

Name: William Malet
Description: William Malet was a minor noble and a key officer in William the Conqueror's army during the Battle of Hastings. Although there is a record to support that he fought in the battle, it is not known of his exact role nor contribution in the invasion. Nevertheless, there is a record that the Duke gave Harold Godwinson's corpse to him for burial instead of accepting Harold's mother's gold offers and he was significantly rewarded with lands and wealth for his contribution to the invasion and became Sheriff of Yorkshire.
para1: William Malet (Not to be confused with his grandson of the same name, William Malet) was the son of unnamed Norman father and Saxon mother. It is possible that William was closely related to both William of Normandy and Harold Godwinson according to unverifiable sources. He was also already a somewhat powerful noble in Normandy prior before the Invasion of England. One of the keyholding of Malet house was the Malet Castle at Graville Sainte Honorine.
para2: William Malet was very likely to accompany William of Normandy in the invasion and participate in the Battle of Hastings, reportedly bravely even after he was dismounted. The norman chronicle wrote that the William of Normandy gave the corpse of Harold Godwinson to William Malet after the battle for the burial ceremony. Harold's corpse was temporarily buried at the cliff near Hastings. William was rewarded handsomely after the battle with new titles and lands.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\malet_1.png
para4: Picture: Malet House’s coat of arms in Iddesleigh Parish Church.
para5: William was granted a large part of the land in Suffolk and Norfolk where he built a Motte and Bailey castle to be his new headquarters. Like many other Motte, there are no longer the remains of William's castle left standing in the present day. He was later appointed the first High Sheriff of Yorkshire after the Siege of York in 1068 AD and was the commander in the defence against Danish Vikings in the later years. He and his family were taken hostage by the Vikings.
para6: He and his family were later released from captivity and safely returned to their holding. William was later appointed High Sheriff of Norfolk and Suffolk by William the Conqueror as a reward for the contribution in defending against the Danish invasion. William died at some point before the Domesday Book survey in 1084 AD and his son, Robert, inherited his title and wealth.

Name: Odo of Bayeux
Description: Another half-brother of William the Conqueror and older brother of Robert of Mortain. Odo of Bayeux was a cleric turned warrior and Earl of Kent renown for his contribution to the Norman invasion. He was also very likely the person who commissioned Bayeux Tapestry, an immensely important historical relic of propagandistic nature that chronicle the events leading up to the Battle of Hastings. Interestingly his life after the invasion was not a pleasant one. After multiple imprisonments and a failed rebellion, he died on his journey for the First Crusade in Sicily.
para1: Odo of Bayeux born in 1036 AD, son of Herluin de Conteville and Herleva, William the Conqueror's mother. Being half-brother to William makes Odo, one of the most prominent companions of William throughout his life. Not much else is known about the activities in his early life, he was a Christian cleric and became bishop of Bayeux in 1049 AD. He was the main figure who participate in the war council for the invasion of England and served as the closest advisor to William.
para2: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\odo_1.png
para4: Picture: Odo during the discussion with William and Robert regarding the building of motte base of operation after the invasion landing.
para5: After the war Council of Lillebonne, Odo contributed to the invasion preparation and accompanied William throughout the invasion. He also participated in the Battle of Hastings, leading the Breton contingents on the left side of the army. As a cleric, his presence alone may already boost the morale of the troop significantly, with the affirmation that the church and no doubt, God, are on their side. If the Tapestry is to be believed, Odo personally fought in the battle along with his men.
para7: Picture: Odo in the Battle of Hastings equipped with a wooden club and rallying his troops.
para8: Victorious from the battle and ultimately the invasion, Odo received a major portion of the war spoils and rewards. He was made the Earl of Kent and controlled the southeast region of the country. During William the conqueror's reign, Odo was the second in power who assist William in court and even served as regent during William's absence. His vast amount of wealth and estates was only second to the king himself.
para9: It is commonly believed that the Bayeux Tapestry was commissioned by Odo to lavishly decorate his cathedral roughly a decade after the invasion. This may explain the mysterious appearance of the three individuals namely, Wadard, Vital and Turold the dwarf servant who were Odo's tenants. The growth of Odo's power and influence came to the abrupt end when William began to view Odo's vast political influence as a threat to his rule.
para12: Picture: Turold the dwarf holding a horse in the Bayeux Tapestry
para13: Odo was subjected to two separate imprisonments on the order of William for different charges in 1076 and 1082 AD, both of which caused great loss to his wealth, title, and his formal perceived authority. There can be no doubt that both Odo and William no longer viewed the another with flavour. After being in prison for around five years in Normandy, William, now on his deathbed, released Odo from prison after being persuaded by Robert, Count of Mortain in 1087 AD.
para14: After William's death, Odo supported William's eldest son, Robert Curthose, in the succession rebellion along with Robert, Count of Mortain. The rebellion failed in the end and Odo with permission of William Rufus was allowed to leave England and continued serving Robert Curthose in Normandy. Later in his life, Odo participated in the First Crusade alongside Robert Curthose. His travel came to an end abrupt on the way to Italy with his death, possibly from old age in his 60s.
para16: Picture: The Bayeux Cathedral during World War 2.

Name: Turstin FitzRolf
Description: Turstin FitzRolf is the name of a person who was a companion of William the Conqueror. With unknown role and accomplishment, it is more likely that he was a knight under William's service than a minor noble. After the invasion, he was granted multiple Baronies and holdings in Somerset.
para1: Turstin Fitz Rolf (Son of Rolf) or Turstin the White was born around 1045 AD in Bec-de-Mortagne, Normandy. There is not much information regarding his family as we only know that his father name was Rolf as the name of Turstin suggested. Not much else is known about his early life, except that he was a knight under William of Normandy. He was one of the minor nobles that participated in the Invasion of England, either to serve his lord or for wealth and glory.
para2: The story went that as the two formally selected knights, namely Raoul II of Tosny and Walter Giffard, rejected Duke William's offer for the standard-bearer, William called upon Turstin to offer the position. Turstin gladly accepted and bear the standard, which as claimed by the Norman sources was provided by the Pope. This means that Turstin would carry the standard throughout the Battle of Hastings nearby Duke William and may even engage in combat with the enemy if the chronicle of William's personal combat to be believed.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\eustace_1.png
para4: Picture: Knight in the Bayeux Tapestry that some consider depicting Turstin as he holds a standard in his hand. Although it is more likely to be Eustace II.
para5: For accomplishing such prestige purpose, Turstin was rewarded with manors around England and the title of Baron of North Cadbury. No tale was written of his deed after the invasion nor his family line, most of the lands that he held seem to be passed on to other families for an unknown reason after his death at some time after 1086 AD.

Name: Geoffrey de Montbray
Description: Geoffrey de Montbray was a Bishop from a noble house and a political advisor for William the Conqueror likely both before and after the invasion. He fought in the Battle of Hastings and participated in multiple battles after against the subsequent rebellions. As a religious cleric, the chronicle remarks that Geoffrey was more skilled in the military matter than his official duty.
para1: Geoffrey de Montbray was born around 1030 AD in Montbray, Normandy. He was the son of Roger de Montbray and an unnamed mother. He was made Bishop of Coutances by his brother, Mauger de Montbray, Archbishop of Rouen, in 1049 AD at age 19 years old. To the surprise of nobody, Geoffrey was accused of simony (buying the bishop title) by the Council of Reims. He had to testimony before Pope Leo IX in that same year and with a skilful speech, Pope Leo IX declared Geoffrey innocence of such crime.
para2: After the council, Geoffrey accompanied the pope for about a year and attended the council at Rome in 1050 AD and personally signed the decree (papal bull) that declares Bishop Gerard of Toul as a saint. During his stay in Italy, there are numerous records of Geoffrey meeting with several prominence church officials and nobles, including the infamous Norman adventurer, Robert Guiscard, who conquered Sicily from the occupied Muslims.
para3: Returning from Italy, Geoffrey began the restoration of religious buildings and faith including enacting a new cathedral in his region. Since the beginning of his career, Geoffrey was involved in the political matter in Normandy as well. He was personally close to Duke William of Normandy and help advise in the matter of state multiple times. This is not to say that he disregarded his duty in the spiritual and religious matter though. And in 1066 AD, he accompanied William in his conquest of England.
para4: For commanding the troops in the Battle of Hastings, Geoffrey was rewarded with a great number of lands across England. Even after the invasion, Geoffrey remained a charismatic aristocrat in William's court and actively participated in the political activity of England under William's rule. Moreover, he was also quite active in the matter of warfare, Geoffrey was presented in the siege of Montacute castle in 1069 AD, 1075 rebellion suppression and even joined Robert de Montbray in the succession rebellion.
para5: Although his name was presented in various battles, it was uncertain what was his role in the army or battle. Some records suggest that he and a group of clerics offered a prayer to the troops before the battles. He also served as the advisor to the commander and very likely to directly participated in the combat. Surprisingly, no record of his name was found to hold any title in England after the invasion. This may indicate that Geoffrey remained simply a close advisor for William throughout his rule.
para6: This warrior bishop was one of the leaders in the failed succession rebellion in 1088 AD. After Bishop Odo of Bayeux surrendered to King William II, Geoffrey seemed to manage to reconcile with William rather quickly and fortunately secured all of his wealth and land in England. Although this reconciliation may come at a cost, as his activity in Normandy dwindled significantly in the later years, indicating that Robert Curthose no longer view Geoffrey with favour and the two became hostile.
para7: No longer a prominent figure in both Normandy and England, Geoffrey remained a wealthy individual and still tried to facilitate the matter between both sides as Geoffrey was likely to be presented during the formal peace treaty between William and Robert in Normandy. In 1091 AD, an earthquake stuck Coutances and was famously interpreted as an omen for Geoffrey's death. Geoffrey suddenly fell ill with stomach pain shortly after and was completely incapacitated by the pain.
para8: After recovering from such illness, Geoffrey organised a public confession for his sins and gave alms to the poor. He also ordered the repair for his church and cathedral, while also organised the curse cleansing. Such event was witnessed by many prominent people such as Bishop Odo of Bayeux and Bishop William of Durham. In 1092 AD, Geoffrey died in his deathbed surrounded by clerics and other people. A funeral was performed and his body was buried in his churchyard.

Name: Robert of Mortain
Description: Robert of Mortain was a Count of Mortain and William the Conqueror's another half-brother who is no doubt one of the closest companions of Duke William. His name is recorded as a participant in the war council and contributor to the invasion fleet. Not much is known for his role in the battle but after the invasion, Robert was rewarded a significant portion of war spoil and land for his contribution. He was also the leader of the failed revolt against William II over the succession dispute.
para1: Robert, Count of Mortain was born around 1031 AD, He is the son of Herluin de Conteville and Herleva of Falaise, and younger brother of Odo of Bayeux. As Herleva was also the mother of William of Normandy, this makes Robert the half-brother of William. Robert was made Count of Mortain by William in 1049 after the banishment of the former count, William Wernlenc. Unfortunately, Robert's early life is not well-recorded until his involvement in the Invasion of England.
para2: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\odo_1.png
para4: Picture: Robert during the discussion with William and Odo regarding the building of motte base of operation after the invasion landing.
para5: Robert along with his brother accompanied William in the conquest. It was recorded that Robert contributed 120 ships to the invasion fleet of around 700 ships, making him one of the major contributor of the invasion. Robert likely presented in the Battle of Hastings although no accomplishment in battle was found. After the successful invasion, Robert was made the Earl of Shrewsbury and rewarded with great wealth and lands.
para6: Robert was indeed a loyal subject of William throughout his life. He was assigned a commander in the defence against Danish invasion in the south, while William the Conqueror marched the royal army to the north in the campaign of so-called "Harrying of the North" in 1069 AD. Unlike William, Robert's relationship with Odo remained amiable as he personally requested William to reconciled with Odo when William was in his deathbed. After William's death, Robert joined Odo in the succession crisis in 1088 AD.
para7: Robert was also here in this conflict identified as the key commander of the rebel force along with Odo against William Rufus. The rebellion failed and Robert was pardoned and none of his title or lands was confiscated, unlike many other conspirators. Robert died in 1095 AD, Normandy, of unknown cause at 64 years old. His body was kept at the Abbey of Grestain next to his father and his wife, Mathilda.

Name: Wadard
Description: Wadard is the name of the person that appear in Bayeux Tapestry and Domesday book who believed to be a nobleman of unknown origin. It was believed that he may be a noble from Bayeux or less possibly a residence near Hastings. Regardless of origin, it is crucial that his name appear in the Tapestry, which indicate his importance to William's court and likely fought in the Battle of Hastings.
para1: Wadard was an individual shrouded in mystery that appears in the Bayeux Tapestry in the scene after Duke William's invading army has landed at Pevensey in the Invasion of England. He wore a hauberk armour and equipped with a kite shield and spear while riding a horse. His duty seems to be the logistic supervisor of the army's ration as depicted in the tapestry with nearby farm animals about to be slaughtered and cooked for banquet.
para2: Wadard was likely to be a direct vassal of Odo of Bayeux as support by the evidence of Domesday Book, which shows that he owned lands in Kent, a region that was Odo's main holding. It was also possible that Wadard was already Odo's vassal long before the conquest with the reasoning that his presence in the tapestry was to confirm that Odo brought his own vassals into the war, thus fulfilled his feudal obligation to William.
para3: Regardless of his status or character, Wadard was no doubt an influential patron that either contributed or paid handsomely to Odo to be embroiled into an expensive piece of art unlike any other. Nevertheless, not much else of his life indicate that he was not part of a major noble house, probably a knight. He and his counterpart, Vital, probably died at some point after the Domesday Book survey in 1088 AD.

Name: Vital
Description: Vital is the name of another person beside Wadard that appear in Bayeux Tapestry. It is believed that he was one of Odo of Bayeux's followers and tenants beside Wadard and the dwarf, Turold. He very likely fought in the Battle of Hastings but not much else is known about his origin, accomplishment and fate after the invasion.
para1: Vital or Vitalis was another mysterious person alongside Wadard who appears in the Bayeux Tapestry in the scene before the Battle of Hastings was commenced where William of Normandy asking Vital about the presence of Harold's army. His depiction in the scene indicates that he likely served as a scout platoon leader and heavily armed enough to possibly fought in the cavalry unit during the battle. No formal record existed that write of his deed in battle still.
para2: Possibly a vassal of Odo similar to Wadard long before the invasion, Vital became a landowner tenant in Canterbury, holding at least two estates at Northbourne and Dover. Vital's deed after the invasion was also recorded at the church he established dedicated to St Edmund the Martyr at Ridingate. A pious knight under a wealthy bishop, Vadard and the other followers of Odo were likely one of the more wealthy subjects in the kingdom at the time.
para3: Vital died at some point after the Domesday Book survey in 1088 AD and his son named Haimo inherited his land. Interestingly enough, Vital's family was well-recorded for a minor noble family. Vital also had a daughter named Matilda and another son who became a monk named Goscelin. Goscelin left the Flemish monastery of Saint-Bertin in St-Omer after 1066 AD to settle in England with his family. Much of Vital and his family's history can be obtained from the letters and records that Goscelin left behind.

Name: Gilbert d'Auffay
Description: Gilbert d'Auffay was one of Norman nobles who followed William the Conqueror to invade England and participated in the Battle of Hastings. After the invasion, he returned to his holding in Normandy and ruled there until his final rest.
para1: Gilbert d'Auffay, born around 1032 AD in Northern Normandy, was son of Richard de Heugleville and Ada. Not much is known about him and his family except that they are from a century-old noble house in Saint-Valery, Northen Normandy. Gilbert became the Lord of Saint-Valery after his father at some point and participated in the conquest of England under William of Normandy in 1066 AD. His unmentioned contribution was likely to be immense enough that King William offered Gilbert some holdings in England as the rewards.
para2: Gilbert declined William's offer and returned to Normandy after the invasion and remained at his holding in Saint-Valery until the end of his time in 1087 AD. His body was buried at the church of Sainte-Marie d'Auffay along with his wife, Beatrix d'Auffay (of Valenciennes), who died later in 1091 AD.

Name: Humphrey I
Description: Humphrey "The Bearded" or "The Old" was a Norman noble who found the house of Bohon. He was also William the Conqueror's godfather and accompanied William in the invasion and participated in the Battle of Hastings. He was rewarded generously for his contribution in invasion and remained a major figure in William's ruling.
para1: Humphrey I de Bohun or Humphrey with the Beard or sometimes the Old, born around 1000 AD in Manche, England, was the son of  Richard de Meri and the Billeheude. He was the first known Bohun family, which continue to exist for at least two centuries after his death. He is remembered for his role of godfather to William the Conqueror and participation in the Battle of Hastings. His nickname originated from the fact that most Norman people at the time shaved their beard routinely.
para2: He was the only known named people to shown having a beard in the Bayeux Tapestry. Humphrey was a religious man, according to William's journal for his charitable acts, such as founding multiple priories and multiple accounts of donation to the churches and monasteries. He accompanied William in the various journeys and the most important fight of his life in the Battle of Hastings in 1066 AD.
para3: IMAGE:ruleset\historical\leader\lore_image\humphrey_1.png
para4: Picture: Bohon House’s coat of arms.
para5: Humphrey became the Baron of Taterford after the invasion and was well rewarded with wealth and lands. He was indeed a rich and powerful nobleman of the time under William's rule with the noblest title "Champion and defender of the throne". He died at some point between 1080 and 1093 of unknown cause and was succeeded by his second son, Richard, as the eldest son died young.

Name: Engenulf of Laigle
Description: Engenulf of Laigle or Engenulphe de Laigle was a Baron of Laigle who accompanied William the Conqueror in the invasion. He died shortly after the Battle of Hastings, possibly while chasing the fleeing Saxon soldiers.
para1: Engenulf of Laigle, son of Fulbert de l'Aigle and Richeride de Normandie, was born around 1010 AD in Deine, Manche. He was part of the Laigel family who ruled over the town of L'Aigle since the rule of Duke Richard II of Normandy. Not much else is known about Engenulf's accomplishment or history except that he accompanied William of Normandy to invade England in 1066 AD. He was the only named person that fought on William's side to died in the Battle of Hastings. Ironically, his death proves that chasing after an already fleeing enemy force does not always guarantee a risk-free kill.

Name: Richard fitz Gilbert
Description: Richard fitz Gilbert was a Norman noble and another half-brother of William the Conqueror. As Richard was an illegitimate son of Gilbert, Count of Brionne, he did not inherit the title when his father died. Richard accompanied William the Conqueror in the Invasion of England and was well rewarded with a vast amount of English lands including the lordship of Clare, in Suffolk. Richard was also part of the succession rebellion in 1088. He was punished severely after the failed rebellion.
para1: Richard fitz Gilbert (also known as Richard de Clare), son of Gilbert, Count of Brionne and Herleva of Falaise, was born around 1030 AD. A bastard son between a local nobleman and a tanner, Richard was also a half-brother to William of Normandy. Richard and his brothers fled to Flanders when his father was murdered by Ralph de Wacy and Robert de Vitot. On his return in 1040 AD, Richard was awarded with the lordship of Bienfaite and Orbec by William due to his father's loyalty.
para2: Richard married Rohese Giffard and had 7 known children together who went on to be considerably important figures in English history later. Richard accompanied William of Normandy in the invasion of England and participated in the Battle of Hastings in 1066 AD. For his accomplishment, Richard was awarded a great amount of land in Kent, Essex, Surrey, Suffolk and Norfolk. Richard became one of the most powerful noblemen during William's rule as was part of the king's council and had the title "Chief Justiciar".
para3: After William's death, Richard joined the side of rebellion for Robert Curthose along with Odo and Robert. The rebellion went badly and during the end, Richard hid in his castle at Tonbridge. William Rufus led an army to lay siege on Tonbridge castle, which lasted only 2 days before Richard surrendered. Richard was severely punished for treason against William by having his Tonbridge castle and city burnt to the ground. Richard was forced to live in a monastery for the rest of his life. He died roughly 3 years later in 1091 AD at the age of around 60 and was buried at St. Neots Priory, Cambridgeshire.

Name: Harold Godwinson
Description: The Saxon king of England, Harold Godwinson is the rightful heir of Edward the Confessor (at least according to himself). Originally the Earl of East Anglia, Harold was already extremely influential person long before his kingship. His short reign of one year as the last Saxon king was nothing short of troubling, having to defend against both invasions from Norse and Norman in the same year. He and his two brothers were killed in the Battle of Hastings thus signal the new reign of Norman in Albion.
para1: Harold II of house Godwinson, son of Godwin of Wessex and Gytha, was born in 1022 AD. House Godwinson was already one of the most powerful families in England, controlling the majority of the south-eastern part of the country. In 1044 AD, his father obtained and bestowed the Earldom of East Angelia to him. Harold also married Edith the Fair at around this time, the marriage was considered to be controversial as many scholars still debated whether the church considered it to be illegitimate or not.
para2: In 1051 AD, Harold's father rebelled against Edward the Confessor for refusing to obey the royal decree to punish the people of Dover who attack Eustace II during his visit. The rebellion failed and his whole family was exiled from England in the same year. Harold and his younger brother, Leofwine, fled to Dublin while the rest of the family sought refuge in Flender. A year later, Harold and his family returned to England with an army and forced Edward to restore the lost earldom to his father, thus restoring the power of Godwinson.
para3: After his father died suddenly in 1053 AD, Harold inherit the Earldom of Wessex and became the most powerful political figure in England, second only to the king himself. In 1057 AD, the death of Leofric and other political rivals allowed Harold to obtained the Earldom of Mercia and Northumbria for his two younger brothers. Godwinson family was no doubt the most powerful house in Saxon England at the time. Even more so as Harold also strengthen the alliance with other powerful Saxon nobles.
para4: Harold also emerge victorious against the Welsh multiple times both in defensive and offensive campaigns, which strengthened his political position even further. In 1064 AD, the Norman chronicle recounted that Harold was sent by Edward to inform William the Bastard of the decision to make William the King of England. The ship Harold was on then got shipwrecked and he got captured by William's vassal. Harold was later released and welcomed by William at the Normandy's court.
para5: With Edward’s death In 1066 AD, Harold claimed that Edward on his deathbed appointed Harold as the "protector" of the kingdom. Harold was then elected as King in the noble council meeting the following day after. Soon after the news of coronation spread, William and  Harald III Hardraade of Norway began planning their own invasions to claim the throne for themselves. Moreover, his previously exiled brother, Tostig Godwinson, also started the rebellion for revenge in the north.
para7: Picture above: Harold swore his fealty and pledged his support to William's inheritance for King of England after his release.                                                                              Picture below: Harold being crowned King of England at Winchester Abbey by the archbishop of York.
para9: Harold managed to fended off Tostig’s initial raids on mutiple regions of England. Before Harald Hardrada's force arrived, Tostig move his raiding target to the northern part of the country. While, Harold still positioned his army in the southern part waiting for William's force to arrived. With the news that Tostig and Harald joined forced, captured York and defeated a local army in the Battle of Fulford, Harold rushed his army up north from London.
para10: Harold's army marched to Yorkshire in 4 days and caught Harald and Tostig' combined force by surprise at Stamford Bridge. According to a Norwegian source, Harold himself rode to Harld and Tostig alone before the battle to convince Tostig to return to his side. The battle began with the English army attempting to cross the bridge, while the Norwegian force start preparing for battle and a lone Norse warrior single-handedly delay the English crossing.
para11: When the English managed to cross the bridge, only a portion of the Norse army managed to form a shield wall and most of them left their armour behind. The battle consisted of the two forces locking in a shield wall engagement for hours. With massive disadvantage, the Norse infantries broke first with both Harald and Tostig killed in the battle subsequently. Although the Norse reinforcement managed to arrive before the battle ended, they were of not much help and could not change the outcome of the battle.
para12: Although victorious, Harold needed to march his army to the south to fight against the second invasion force led by William. The forced march was so taxing that a good portion of the army was left behind on the way. Upon reaching Hastings, Harold camped his force at Caldbec Hill and his troops held a feast for an entire night to prepare for the upcoming battle. In the early morning, Harold marched his force with the plan to catch William's army off-guard similar to the prior battle but failed. The Battle of Hastings commenced and ended with his death.
para14: Picture: Harold shot by an arrow through the eye in the midst of the battle.

Name: Gyrth Godwinson
Description: Gyrth Godwinson was the younger brother of Harold Godwinson, King of England. Godwinson was one of the most powerful houses during the reign of Edward the Confessor, Gyrth himself hold multiple Earldom in East England along with his brothers. Along with his brothers, Gyrth commanded a significant portion of the Saxon army in the Battle of Hastings. It is believed that Gyrth is killed by William the Conqueror himself in personal combat as recorded in multiple sources.
para1: Gyrth Godwinson, son of Godwin of Wessex and Gytha, was born in 1032 AD. He was a younger brother of Harold Godwinson. He and his family were exiled for life by the order of King Edward the Confessor in 1051 AD. Gyrth and the rest of his family fled to Flanders, while Leofwine and Harold fled to Dublin. The Godwinson family returned to England again a few years later after Harold marched his army to forced King Edward to restore their former position and wealth.
para2: After becoming an established and powerful family again, Harold made his brothers, Gyrth and Leofwine, the Earl of many important regions in the east of England. Gyrth was one of the members that joined Harold's march up north and participated in the Battle of Stamford Bridge in 1066 AD. Their victory and celebration over Harald Hardrada came to an abrupt end when the news of William of Normandy landing in the south came a few days later.
para3: Gyrth again joined his brothers in the march to the Battle of Hastings with numerous of his Huscarl retinues and fyrd militias. It was written in several records that Gyrth personally got into argument with Harold several times before the battle took place trying to persuade his brother to not rush the army to intercept William's force and rather fight a defensive war and employ a scorch earth tactic. Further that Gyrth attempt to discourage Harold from personally leading the army into combat.
para4: It was told in the chronicles and stories that Gyrth personally killed William of Normandy's first warhorse in the chaotic combat but was quickly slain by the Duke shortly after. Gryth and his two brothers fell in the battle and cause panic among the troops, sealing the destiny of Saxon England forever. With no leader left to assume the role of commander, Saxon's army fled the battle while the remaining Huscarls fought to avenge their lord until the last breath.
para6: Picture: Death of Gyrth and Leofwine in the Battle of Hastings.

Name: Leofwine Godwinson
Description: Leofwine Godwinson was the younger of Harold Godwinson and Earl of multiple regions in East England. Having followed Harold throughout his life, it is interesting to note that Leofwine and the other brother did not fight in the Battle of Stamford Bridge. Nevertheless, Leofwine along with his two brothers fought and perished in the Battle of Hastings.
para1: Leofwine Godwinson, son of Godwin of Wessex and Gytha, was born in 1035 AD. He was a younger brother of Harold Godwinson. Not much is known about his childhood only except that when the Godwinson family was exiled in 1051 AD, Leofwine accompanied Harold to Ireland and help to gather an army to invade England in the following year. After his father died in 1053 AD, Leofwine became one of the most powerful noblemen during Godwinson's rule as the Earl of East England regions.
para2: Leofwine did not participate in the Battle of Stamford Bridge against Harold Hadrada but accompanied his brother to intercept William of Normandy invasion at Senlac hill and participated in the Battle of Hastings as one of the commanders in 1066. Not much else was recorded of his accomplishment during the battle except that he was killed alongside two of his brothers before the battle ended in Saxon's defeat. Interestingly, the record of his death in battle is somewhat obscured. While some sources suggest that Leofwine command part of the army further from his two brothers, William of Poitiers and the Bayeux Tapestry seem to suggest that the he and his brother, Gyrth, died near each other.
para6: Picture: Death of Gyrth and Leofwine in the Battle of Hastings.

Name: Godric of Berkshire
Description: Godric was a Saxon sheriff of Berkshire who fought in the Battle of Hastings on the side of Harold Godwinson's army. Not much is known about Godric beside his land ownership and title from the Domesday Book. But according to the chronicle of the monastery of Abingdon, he was part of a few named individuals killed during the battle.
para1: Godric of Berkshire was a high sheriff from Berkshire. According to the survival record of his landownership, Godric was one of the more wealthy and powerful landowners/nobles with several holdings in various regions. He accompanied Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings and died in combat and his possessions became invalid for this treason when William the Conqueror became the King of England.

Name: Thurkill
Description: Thurkill was one of the landowners or thanes who participated in the Battle of Hastings on Harold Godwinson's side. Most of the thanes were the leader of the Fyrd militias, while the noble led alongside the Huscarls. Thurkill, along with many other unnamed thanes and nobles, perished in the battle along with their kings. Thus, leaving a vast amount of land to be claimed as war spoil by William the Conqueror.

Name: Edric the Deacon
Description: Edric the Deacon was a landowner (thane) from Suffolk who joined Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings and perished along with many others. Besides his ownership evident from Domesday book, which also indicates his death, not much else is known.

Name: Breme
Description: Another landowner (thane) from Suffolk who joined Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings. Breme along with Thurkill and Edric the Deacon are one of many thanes who perished in the battle.
para6: Odo of Bayeux born in 1036 AD, son of Herluin de Conteville and Herleva, William the Conqueror's mother. Being half-brother to William makes Odo, one of the most prominent companions of William throughout his life. Not much else is known about the activities in his early life, he was a Christian cleric and became bishop of Bayeux in 1049 AD. He was the main figure who participate in the war council for the invasion of England and served as the closest advisor to William.

Name: Aelfwig of New Minster
Description: Aelfwig was an abbot (head of a monastery) of New Minster during the Invasion of England. He and twelve fellow monks joined Harold's force in the Battle of Hastings. Equipped with monk robe and chainmail, they are no doubt one of the literal warrior monks one often seen in a fictional story. Aelfwig was, unfortunately, one of the few named individuals that perished on Senlac Hill, likely along with his fellow monks.
para1: Aelfwig of New Minster was believed to be a brother of Earl Godwine of Wessex and therefore uncle of Harold Godwinson. He became the abbot of New Minster in 1063 AD. Not much information is available about him except that he and twelve other monks participated in the Battle of Hastings on the side of Harold's force and perished in combat similar to other named individuals who fought valiantly for the cause and loyalty.

Name: Aelfric
Description: Aelfric was a landowner (thane) from Huntingdonshire who participated in  Battle of Hastings on the side of Harold Godwinson. He perished along with many others that day.

Name: Son of Helloc
Description: An unnamed warrior who was recorded to fight on the side of Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings. He was believed to be a Huscarl of Gyrth Godwinson who managed to kill William of Normandy second horse in the battle with a javelin. He was then cut down by William himself who proceeded to rush into the Saxon rank with rage after two of his warhorses fell.

Name: Thutmose III
Description: Pharaoh Thutmose III of the New Kingdom was one of the greatest Pharoah in Ancient Egypt history. He expanded his empire into from Nubia to Syria in 20 successful military campaigns. The Battle of Megiddo against Canaan city-states was his first campaign. Excel in both government and military, his rule developed the New Kingdom into the world first superpower that no country could rival it.
para1: Thutmose III, son of Thutmose II and his second wife Iset, was born around 1504 BC. With his father early death at the age of 31, Thutmose III became the sixth Pharaoh of the New Kingdom at the age of 2. Because of his young age, his stepmother, Hatshepsut, was first crowned as the fifth Pharoah regent until Thutmose III reached around twenty years of age when Hatshepsut died. Thutmose III was considered a military genius by many historians with the nickname "the Napoleon of Egypt" for his grandiose accomplishment.
para2: When Thutmose III was around the age of 21, the Canaanite city-states formed an alliance and start a rebellion against their Egyptian master. Led by the unnamed King of Kadesh, the Canaanite alliance mustered an army at the City of Megiddo. Thutmose III started his first-ever military campaign by marching his army to the city and thus start the Battle of Megiddo. The battle ended with Egyptian victory and surrender of the Canaanite alliance after the long Siege of Megiddo.
para3: The first campaign was a turning point for the New Kingdom's prosperity as all of the Canaan city-states were again reinstate as vassals and contribute greatly to the empire's wealth. Thutmose III then continued to campaign against the remaining Canaan and Syrian city-states for another 20 years at a total of 14 military campaigns. During his reign, Thutmose III also commissioned various temples and tombs such as Karnak temple and Lateran Obelisk.
para4: With Canaan and Syria in his control, Thutmose III led his last 15th campaign against Nubia at around the age of 50 but could not completely conquer it. Thutmose III died in 1425 BC at the age of 56. His body was mummified and buried in the Valley of the Kings. His mummified body was severely damaged by grave robbers and later moved to the Boulak Museum of Egyptian Antiquities along with many other Pharoahs' bodies in modern time.

Name: King of Kadesh
Description: An Unnamed King of Kadesh who led the city-states rebellion against the New Kingdom shortly after Pharaoh Thutmose III ascend to the throne. He and the other leaders of nearby Canaanites nation and tribe probably wait for the right moment to start this rebellion since the reign of the previous Pharoah Hatshepsut. Personally led the army in the Plain of Megiddo but lost against the brilliant military mind of Napoleon of Ancient Egypt. He and his allies surrendered after the Siege of Megiddo and sent the sons as a hostage to Egypt.

Name: Prince of Megiddo
Description: An Unnamed Prince of Megiddo who participated in the rebellion against the New Kingdom along with other Canaanite city-states coalition. The prince took part in the Battle of Megiddo and fled from the field during the retreat. While his fate after the battle was not exactly recorded, it is reasonable to believe that Thutmose III might spare his life along with other rebellion leaders.

para1: Taillefer was a jongleur, which is a Norman equivalent of minstrel and clown, that accompanied William's army to England in 1066. Possibly served as an entertainer for the army, but not much of his story is known as it can only be found in the Norman chronicle that was written long after the Battle of Hastings. Neither his name nor depiction is recorded in the Bayeux Tapestry. If the story is to be believed, he was well versed in the art of swordsmanship.
para2: According to the legends, Taillefer went to the front of the Saxon army and sang Chanson de Roland or Song of Roland while juggling his sword to taunt the enemy. The taunt was indeed successful as a Saxon warrior rushed to cut him down. Taillefer then won the duel and proceeded to rush into Saxon's line alone. He managed to slay four enemy warriors before being overwhelmed and killed.

Name: Taillefer
Description: Taillefer was the name of the jongleur or clown that led the Norman army into battle during the Battle of Hastings, according to various Norman chronicles. He sang the Song of Roland and juggled his sword while the troops walked behind him. Some chronicles also mentioned that he managed to cut down several Saxon challengers and rushed into the enemy line while singing.
